#Text=Lucy A. Mallory
#Text=Lucy A. Mallory ( c. 1843 or 1856 — September 4 , 1920 ) was an American writer , publisher , editor , and spiritualist . [ 1 ]
#Text=She was also a " suffragist , vegetarian , and devotee of metaphysical experiences " .

column1: #Text=Leo Tolstoy was so influenced by Mallory 's magazine , the monthly spiritualist , [ 2 ] The World 's Advance Thought , [ 3 ] that he called her the " greatest woman in America " . [ 4 ]

column1: #Text=Mallory was editor and publisher of The World 's Advance Thought and the Universal Republic — two periodicals printed under one cover — published for more than thirty years . [ 5 ]
#Text=Early years
#Text=Lucy A. Rose was born c. 1843 [ 6 ] in Michigan [ 7 ] and grew up in Roseburg , Oregon . [ 8 ] [ lower-alpha 1 ]
#Text=Her father , Aaron Rose , settled in Oregon early in the 1840s , and the city of Roseburg was named for him .
#Text=He was one of the first European settlers at a time when the country was an unbroken wilderness .
#Text=Her mother , Minerva Kellogg Rose , [ 2 ] died in giving birth to Lucy .
#Text=Mallory was reared among Native Americans . [ 8 ] [ 11 ]
#Text=Career

#Text=On June 24 , 1860 , she married Rufus Mallory , [ 12 ] who afterwards represented Oregon in Congress , and who was later one of the most successful lawyers in the Pacific Northwest , and was the senior member of the extensive law firm to which Senator Joseph N. Dolph belonged .
#Text=She accompanied her husband to Washington , D.C. , after which they returned to Salem , Oregon . [ 4 ] [ 8 ] [ 11 ]

#Text=In 1874 , the old slavery prejudice was so strong in Oregon that some forty-five African American and mulatto children were prevented from attending the Salem public schools and kept from all chance of acquiring an education , as no Caucasian teachers would condescend to teach them .
#Text=A public fund was set apart for them , but no one came forward to labor for it .
#Text=Mallory volunteered to instruct the children , in the face of sneers and ridicule .
#Text=Her course shamed the people into a sense of duty , and within three years , friction and opposition ended , and the children were admitted into the public schools and classes .
#Text=Mallory , having no immediate use for the public money which she drew for her work , let it remain in the bank . [ 4 ] [ 8 ] [ 11 ]

#Text=In 1886 , she used the fund for the purchase of a printing plant , and soon after , started her monthly magazine , the World 's Advanced Thought , with Judge Horatio N. Maguire for assistant editor .

#Text=After Maguire retired from editorial connection , on account of the pressure of other business affairs , he still contributed to its pages , while Mallory , who was always the proprietor , had full control .
#Text=Her magazine circulated among advanced thinkers and workers .
#Text=Tolstoy subscribed to it . [ 8 ] [ 11 ]
#Text=Mallory established and maintained the first free reading room in Portland .
#Text=For thirty years , it was open to all who would enter it .
#Text=In it were many rare books of spiritualism and philosophy , as well as periodicals , not easily obtainable elsewhere .
#Text=Mallory , with her All World Soul Communion hour , to be observed around the world , was the pioneer in the " going into the Silence " idea , collectively .
#Text=Many New Thought groups have since practised this method of attaining unity of thought .
#Text=In addition to her reading room and periodicals , Mallory kept parlors open for meetings held twice or three times a week .

#Text=Often these were addressed by speakers of world reputation , but oftener , those with unusual ideas spoke there as the one place in the city where they could utter their thoughts in a friendly and hospitable atmosphere .
#Text=Many tried their speaking powers here for the first time .
#Text=Elizabeth Towne , publisher of Nautilus Magazine , Holyoke , Massachusetts , was one of these . [ 5 ]
#Text=Prince & Schaffer ( 2017 ) described Mallory as an " anarchist creative " with her cultural club , the Association of Artists and Authors . [ 4 ]
#Text=Mallory was always a vegetarian . [ 8 ] [ 11 ]
#Text=Mallory was a Life Member of the National American Woman Suffrage Association . [ 13 ]
#Text=In the early 1900s , the Oregon Vegetarian Society held meetings in the " Advance Thought " parlor at the Hotel Mallory , the parlor being owned by Mallory . [ 9 ]

column1: #Text=Personal life
#Text=Notice of Mallory 's memorial , " Women 's Activities " .
#Text=The Morning Oregonian . XXXIX ( 38 ) .
#Text=September 19 , 1920 .
#Text=p.10 .
#Text=Her work , like that of her husband , was in Portland , but their home was on their ranch or fruit farm , 4 miles ( 6.4km ) out in the suburbs of the city . [ 8 ]
#Text=She had two children , Elmer Ellsworth ( 1862 – 1918 ) , and Lulu ( 1872-1872 ) , who died after 13 days . [ 12 ] [ 14 ]
#Text=Mallory died in 1920 . [ 4 ]
#Text=Death
#Text=Mallory died at age 76 in San Jose , California . [ 6 ]
